div.p: ANTONIO: We've seen how high-risk alcohol or drug use can alter our brains, leaving us with less pleasure and more stress.
ANTONIO: But, there are additional concerns for those making high-risk choices in their teenage or young-adult years. Ray, can you tell us a little bit more about this.
RAY: Sure. To understand this additional risk, we need to have a little background on brain development. At around the age of 12, the brain begins to go through a massive redesign.
RAY: This generally starts in the back of the brain, and works its way forward to the front.
RAY: By the time a person is in their late teens and young adult years, most of this brain development is finished, but not all of it.
RAY: These changes continue until sometime in the mid-twenties. So, why is this important? Let's look more closely.
RAY: The last part of the brain to go through this reshaping is the prefrontal cortex, which is located right behind the eyes.
RAY: The prefrontal cortex is responsible for executive brain functions. It's the part of the brain that gives us the ability do adult things...
RAY: No... not sex. Adult things like prioritizing what's important, planning, organizing, and sticking to a task until it's done.
RAY: It's what allows us to control our emotions, evaluate ourselves, and -- when necessary -- change our behavior.
RAY: Think about itâ€”children don't do these things very well. Teenagers tend to do them better than children.
RAY: And adults are usually even better at them than teenagers. This is because the adult prefrontal cortex is more developed.
RAY: The high-risk use of alcohol or drugs can slow this development, leaving people stuck in adolescent ways of responding even as they move into their adult years.
RAY: They may be less able to control their emotions, less able to prioritize, plan, or delay gratification now to get better long-term rewards later.

RAY: It's not that they cannot do these things, but they have to work harder at them, and they may fail more often. It's ironic; young people may be pulled into making high-risk choices, thinking it's what adults do.
RAY: But high-risk choices can prevent people from developing adult ways of responding to life's challenges.

RAY: Compound that slowed development with the loss of pleasure, and increased stress, and it can lead people into a pattern of high-risk choices that increase the risk for addiction and other problems.
RAY: If we've been making high-risk choices, this could be a time to use our best thinking to re-evaluate what we've been doing, and where we want to go from here.
RAY: But because of these brain changes, we may have to work harder than most, to do that.
RAY: Good intentions aren't enough to succeed in making a change. This may be particularly true for alcohol and drugs. We've just learned that high-risk choices change our brain.
RAY: So, if we want to succeed... once we change our mind, we must also change our brain.
